title: From paralysis to the LEJOGLE record: Could this ultracyclist beat the there-and-back record?
content:
Cyclist
From paralysis to the LEJOGLE record: Could this ultracyclist beat the there-and-back record?

Imagine taking up cycling less than three years ago, and already deciding it was time for a world record attempt.

As crazy as that might seem, this is the story of Dr Sarah Ruggins, who this May will attempt to break the outright record for cycling from Land’s End to John o’ Groats and back again.

Covering a total of 2,700km with 16,000 metres of elevation, the current LEJOGLE record stands at five days 18 hours, which was recorded in 2017 by James MacDonald, while the women’s record is ten days and five hours held by Louise Harris, which she set in 2023.

Pushing limits and breaking records

Ruggins is aiming to complete the ride in five and a half days, which means she will need to ride between 500km and 600km every day. That would be a staggering challenge for any elite athlete. For someone who only started cycling less than three years ago it’s an extraordinary feat.

It wasn’t long into her cycling journey that she got into ultracycling, and she rode the 2023 and 2024 editions of the Transcontinental Race, plus the Race Around Rwanda.

‘I respond well to really aggressive targets from a mindset perspective,’ Ruggins says. ‘My first bike race was the TCR, which taught me that a lot of our limits are in our mind, and that I put restrictions on myself when I don’t have to, so setting a really aggressive target like the all-time record is a way for me to confront that and allow me to really push myself as hard as I think I can.’

Route choice

The Land’s End to John o’ Groats route is well known, but going for the overall record means Ruggins’s team needs to ensure she can navigate traffic and cities as fast as possible.

‘The cities are really difficult and we want to avoid too many stop lights and things like that,’ she says. ‘Through Exeter, even though we’re on the ring roads, it will be incredibly busy so we know that I’m going to lose the follow cars when I get there.

‘When we get to these busy areas that we can’t avoid, the crew will be doing a hand-off to me before the city limits and then the second support vehicle will be waiting for me on the other side.

‘The part I’m most looking forward to is crossing the border into Scotland. I spent six years of my life in Edinburgh, and it has a very special place in my heart, so I think I’ll get a big boost of energy knowing I’m heading for that border.’

It’s worth noting that the Guinness World Record allows for either route – LEJOGLE or JOGLEJOG – because the record is officially just the fastest return journey between the two furthest points in the UK on a bicycle.

Riders choose their direction based on expected conditions at the time of their record attempt, with MacDonald having chosen JOGLEJOG for his 2017 record due to the weather conditions.

Relentless training

Training for such a gruelling ride requires a huge amount of motivation and discipline from Ruggins, especially around her full-time job at St James’s Place, one of the UK’s largest wealth managers.

‘I think relentless is the only word to describe the training. Over the winter, I was on about 14 hours a week in the saddle, but now it’s ramped up to over 24 hours a week.

‘So I have my nine to five, and I train two hours before work, two hours after work, and I have three to four gym sessions every week on top of that for my strength training.

‘My alarm goes off at around 4:00, I’ll do my two-hour session on the bike and then I’ll get to the gym for 7:30, do an hour at the gym and then get ready and go to work.’

Sleep strategy

To beat the record and ride nearly 600km a day, Ruggins will push her sleep deprivation boundaries to the limit.

‘I’m nervous about the sleep,’ she says. ‘When I did the Transcontinental Race, I had it down to about three hours a night and that was over a 12-day period so I know what that feels like, but I don’t know what less than that feels like.

‘Originally, I was planning on two hours a night, but we’re going to compress that down and I’m hoping to sleep for five hours over the total period of five and a half days.

‘It’s not going to be too regimented but managed by my crew, who will monitor my wobbliness on the bike and whether or not I’m able to keep it upright. The crew will tell me when I can and cannot sleep.

‘Falling asleep on the downhill is a really big risk for me, so I need them to be with me on the downhills and not being afraid to lay on the horn if they see my head slump.’

Her story

Years before her ultracycling career, Ruggins was diagnosed with Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS), which forced her to give up a promising running career and left her bedridden for several years. She needed round-the-clock care and lost the ability to walk and use her hands.

‘CRPS is really severe nerve pain that will leave people bedridden or in a wheelchair for the rest of their lives, she explains. ‘Most often it develops after surgery. I had surgery on my feet because I had a running injury at the time, and your nervous system just inflames and starts telling you that you have third degree burns or broken bones all over your body when you don’t.

‘I got that pain, but then I also got the paralysis of all of my limbs, so I couldn’t move as well. Typically for treatment they give you traditional pain blockers for pain management, but that didn’t work very well as it just made me into a zombie.

‘Then you go through desensitisation therapy, where they train your body into understanding that things shouldn’t hurt you. They would rub a washcloth on your arm, which felt like knives, but they would have to do that over and over and over for months until my body retrained itself to know that that feeling didn’t hurt.’

The experience of overcoming this devastating illness has left Ruggins with not just a profound motivation to see what she is physically capable but also a high pain threshold.

‘After having been through that and knowing that I could sit with that for years, these kind of events now are just a little bit of discomfort, so they don’t really phase me that much, and I’m not scared of much anymore,’ she says.

Closing chapters

For Ruggins, going for this record is a way to turn the page on that particularly difficult period of her life.

‘I was going to be a runner, I was going to be a competitive athlete in the Olympics and then that got taken away from me because of a life-changing illness.

‘I struggled so much with mental health after my recovery and with doubting myself and my new capabilities. Doing this event and pushing myself to the limit and feeling the discomfort will be a way to experience some of the things that I felt when I was ill, but coming at it from a place of strength now.

‘I’m choosing to feel this way and I’m choosing to push myself, and I think that’s going to help me close the chapter.

‘Cycling for me has just given me freedom, and it’s given me a whole new community of people that I didn’t know existed, and I’m terrified for the record, but extremely grateful to be able to go for it.’

It’s also not just about breaking the LEJOGLE record, but also an opportunity to help others.

Alongside the attempt she is raising money for the Bike Project and Bikes for Refugees, which help alleviate transportation poverty in England and Scotland.

Ruggins will start her LEJOGLE record attempt on either 11th or 12th May 2025, depending on weather conditions. To follow along visit www.lejogle.org.

The post From paralysis to the LEJOGLE record: Could this ultracyclist beat the there-and-back record? appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Will Strickson | Website Editor
